Description: Small terracotta figure of comic actor or satyr, portly figure, standing in squarely frontal pose with hands brought round to support his stomach. Traces of fine white coating. Fine orange-pink fabric with a soapy texture. Missing head, back and from thigh-level down.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar to mid 4th century BC Attic representations of comic actors playing slaves (Higgins 1970, 737, 740, 741). Parallel from the Sanctuary of Artemis Paralia, Cyprus (GR 1866,0101.354). Close parrallel, possibly from same mould series, of mid 4th century BC date and attributred to Athens (Chesterman1974, 43, no. 40; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge GR85e. 1937). The fabric suggests this could be of East Greece production.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.401) (Phase 3)
